video.title: React Course - Beginner's Tutorial for React JavaScript Library [2022]
video.description:
Learn React by building eight real-world projects and solving 140+ coding challenges. You can also follow this course interactively on Scrimba: https://scrimba.com/learn/learnreact

React is one of the most popular front-end JavaScript libraries for building user interfaces. After completing this course, you will be able to build web apps in modern React, using patterns like functional components and hooks.

✏️ This teacher is Bob Ziroll, Head of Education at Scrimba. 

Code is available on the Scrimba course page for each lesson.

Scrimba on YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/c/Scrimba
Bob on Twitter: https://twitter.com/bobziroll

replies.author: Ilya Plyusnin
replies.text:
I had the same issue. The imports don't seem to be playing nice with the CDN method but he explains the correct way of setting it up locally a little bit later in the video from 1:33:07 to 1:41:30. Once you have that up and running, you can actually use the imports the same way he does. Do keep in mind that the way he's been rendering stuff up to this point is no longer supported in the latest version of React. I'll use a piece of code from a comment I found here as well to show the new way: const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root')) root.render(

Demo

) I hope this helped you!

topLevelComment.author: R Wright
topLevelComment.text: I'm curious about the reason why it is considered best practice to use the callback function when setting the state rather than just declaring the state?

replies.author: R Wright
replies.text:
@James D. I figured it out. You never want to affect your initial state, the default value/object/array you pass to the variable. You only need the callback function if you are referencing your previous state, otherwise you are simply declaring what your new state should be via return within the "setX" function.

The main takeaway is simply not to write your desired new state to the the initial state variable. Always use the set function to create the new state.

topLevelComment.author: Joshua Sorkin
topLevelComment.text:
I set up the first project as shown at 10:30, but it will not run on Chrome if I just open index.html in the browser as a static file.  It gives the error:

---
Access to XMLHttpRequest at 'file:///C:/my/folder/first-react/index.js' from origin 'null' has been blocked by CORS policy: Cross origin requests are only supported for protocol schemes: http, data, chrome, chrome-extension, chrome-untrusted, https, isolated-app.
---

This is because the standalone Babel is trying to submit all "text/babel" scripts via XMLHttpRequest, which Chrome has blocked in pages opened as 'file://' as a security measure.

To run the first-react project correctly in Chrome, you will need to set up a web server (e.g. Express) that renders index.html at one of its endpoints.

The issue has been documented on React's GitHub here: https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/issues/2038

A pull request was submitted to update the documentation to warn users about this issue here:
https://github.com/reactjs/reactjs.org/pull/2040

As of this writing the pull request has not yet been merged into the documentation.

topLevelComment.author: Raj Abishek
topLevelComment.text:
Small correction at 55:10 — Browsers don’t understand JSX out of the box. Hence we rely on compilers like Babel/Typescript that transform JSX into traditional Javascript that browsers understand. When we create a project locally with toolkits like create-react-app it includes a JSX transformer for us. This transforms the JSX we write into React.createElement(...) calls. Each JSX element is just syntactic sugar for calling React.createElement(component, props, ...children). Eg:

Content

becomes React.createElement('p', null, 'Content') and hence we need to import React for our transformed code to use createElement method. Though we don’t call this method directly, this is what happens under the hood. So technically, anything you can do with JSX can also be done with just plain JavaScript. Now since React 17 things are a little different. Instead of transforming JSX to React.createElement calls, the new JSX transform automatically also imports what it needs. For the same example, this is what happens internally. import {jsx as _jsx} from 'react/jsx-runtime'; _jsx('h1', { children: 'Hello world' }); Since the compiler already imports what it needs you can write JSX without having to explicitly import React. This makes more sense right? If you’re just writing JSX and don’t use any React.createElement() calls in your code then why bother importing it?

topLevelComment.author: TC
topLevelComment.text:
10:41:45 little bug here. If we delete the note that is selected, the text on the right will still update to the topmost note that still exists, but the currentNoteId won't be updated, and then there's a weird bug where you click on the text in the editor, but can't write/change anything, without re-selecting the note in the sidebar.

I added a useEffect with a notes.length depedency.
React.useEffect(() => {
        const idArr = notes.map(note => note.id) //make array of existing notes' ids
        ! idArr.includes(currentNoteId) // check if currentNoteId is in the array
        ? setCurrentNoteId(oldId => notes[0].id) // if not, set the currentNoteId to the topmost note
        : undefined //else do nothing
    }, [notes.length])

this checks for changes in the length of the notes array (granted, it fires needlessly on new note adds), and checks if the currentNoteId is in the array, and if not, resets the currentNoteId to the first note in the array

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
I'd agree that we probably need to put more effort into teaching people how to get things set up on a local machine. However, as someone who's taught web dev frameworks for over 7 years now, I've found that starting out with teaching the local setup causes a huge dropoff in student interest and tends to spike people's imposter syndrome. Scrimba takes all that away by obfuscating the complicated stuff so people can focus their efforts on learning the syntax of the library.

Since this course wasn't originally recorded for YouTube, it's main focus isn't on teaching local setup. The downside is everyone coming to fCC to watch it is at a bit of a disadvantage because they need to read between some lines and figure a few things out on their own, which is exactly what we're trying to avoid at Scrimba.

Still, you're right that people aren't going to write their prod code in Scrimba's editor (which is just VS Code under the hood), but a bonus of that approach is they can worry about the details after they feel comfortable with the syntax instead of trying to do it at the same time.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
I'd agree that I probably need to add some content that goes back and emphasizes the way to do some of the more complex local setup stuff. Currently it's just stuffed into the middle of the course, but never really revisited meaningfully.

That said, I'd argue that doing the course on Scrimba is a better way to learn the material. Then following up on the local environment is a separate learning curve that you work on AFTER learning the topic at hand (React in this case).

You can always get help from the Scrimba or fCC discord communities if you get stuck on something specific to your environment. But I can't tell you how many times I've tried to follow a YouTube lesson on something, only to get caught up with the environment setup that wasn't working out like the person in the video.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: @Oncopoda I welcome feedback and adapt my teaching accordingly all the time. I’m just trying to give context behind why it’s taught the way it is. That said, since Scrimba has a relationship with fCC, we may start doing more to teach off-Scrimba topics to help people watching our tutorials on YouTube instead. And to lessen the learning curve involved with setting up code on a local environment.

replies.author: Oncopoda
replies.text:
@Bob Ziroll I did move on to another video dude, obviously. Instead of getting so defensive maybe learn to take feedback. It's the only way you'll improve as a teacher. 

A developer than can only use React on Scrimba does NOT know React. I understand it sounds harsh, especially when you've worked hard on something, but it's valid critique.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
The course was originally recorded on Scrimba, not intended to be viewed anywhere else. After it was recorded, we agreed to have it put on fCC's YouTube channel.

So yes, a course recorded originally only for Scrimba is insisting on using Scrimba because that was the only option at the time. Not sure I understand which part of that upsets you so much, but maybe the added context will bring some clarity.

Having taught web dev to beginners for > 7 years now, I've learned that React can be a bit overwhelming for students when they have to learn the syntax and how to "think in React" alongside also struggling with local environment setup and differences from one computer to the next. Not sure how many times I've given up on a tutorial because the teacher's environment worked when mine wasn't. What Scrimba sacrifices in teaching local setup, it gains back by reducing disparate environment issues, reducing imposter syndrome when someone gets lost in the setup process, and lowering the bar to having students actually write code alongside the instructor instead of just watching without practicing.

Anyway, feel free to move along to another React tutorial. No one's forcing you to watch this free content that took me ~4 months to make.

topLevelComment.author: James Ramil Alcantara de Soriano
topLevelComment.text: For reference Im over two hours in, I think the course is taught well but I dont think this course is a fit for me and I will not be continuing it. I was following the course while using vscode but the constant conversion from scrimba to vscode makes the course jarring to follow. Do note that this is only the case because I chose to run it locally and the course does walk you through how to set that up but afterwards it will continue to use scrimba. To anyone thinking of following the course I suggest that you follow through using scrimba as the course does, if you don't want to use scrimba then another course might be a better fit for you, which is what I will be doing. For what its worth I think the course does what it says it does, it teaches you react, but the falling out for me is that web development using react isn't done with scrimba and I prefer to learn how development works while also learning technologies like react. Still a massive thanks to the scrimba team though, I do hope that maybe one day they will also make courses that will fit for use cases like mine.

topLevelComment.author: Bechem Gaston
topLevelComment.text:
//Complex State//
Please how did he manage to render the object properties e.g {contact.firstName} while the setContact function was idle? I'm trying but i get the error: 'setContact' is assigned a value but never used. PLease HELP HELP HELP

replies.author: Bechem Gaston
replies.text: @Sam Berg Thanks man, I finally figured it out

replies.author: Sam Berg
replies.text:
If you look at the "error" message you're getting, you will see that it is actually a warning.  Based on the warning you're getting, it sounds like you never use the setContact function you get from calling React.useState.  I don't remember what part of the video you're in so I can't really walk you through it.  But basically you need to figure out what is supposed to trigger changing the contact.  Wherever that is supposed to happen, you need to call setContact(x), where x is the value contact is supposed to be.  For example a 1 line version, if you wanted this to happen when a button is pressed, the jsx would look something like <button onClick={() => {setContact(x)}}>Click me</button>.  It is important that you have the onClick={() => {setContact(x)}} instead of just onClick={setContact(x)}.  The difference is that in the correct version, you are creating a function which CALLS setContact with a value of x to the onClick.  If you do it the other way, you are actually calling the function setContact, instead of passing in a function that calls setContact.

I don't think I was super clear, but hopefully it helps.  Reply if you still are confused, I'll do my best to help.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text:
Because I design my curriculum to be a gradual progression with lots of practices/challenges along the way. It’s not meant to be a shotgun spray of information, but a guided curriculum to help people actually internalize the content. Otherwise it’s just “tutorial hell” where you watch the course, feel like you’re learning something, but then can’t actually write it by yourself.

There are other “React crash courses” out there if you’re looking for an overview. My course here is providing a skill-building way to learn instead.

replies.author: Bob Ziroll
replies.text: It's best practice in React, whenever you need to reference the old state to determine the new state, that you use the callback function and use the old state passed in the parameter to that callback function. I mention this multiple times throughout the course. In your case, it's working fine (and mostly likely will continue to work) but if another state change were ever introduced, React may end up with a race condition and not update the state the way you'd expect. If instead you use a callback function to update the state, you'll never have that problem.

topLevelComment.author: Brooks Gunn
topLevelComment.text:
Gonna start this today (February 5, 2022). Will update each day I get to do it.

*_February 12_* : Got to Timestamp #24 ~ 2 hours in. Would've done more, but it's Valentine's Day weekend! 

There is so much meat in just these two hours. Do the excersises at least up until this point on Scrimba, you won't regret it. The platform is so cool. I know I'm gonna relearn then learn a lot already.

If you are a beginner, make sure you have at least a medium-well grasp of ES6 syntax. It will help a lot when having to remember Vanilla JS methods. I took a minute to remember createElement myself, because React just makes it so easy. It's simply a function with a return block that contains the HTML you want executed and the querySelector - not JS but JSX style. That's the advantage of using this awesome *declarative* language where it's easier to type exactly what you mean. *Imperative* Vanilla JS takes many more instructions and you have be very explicit, wasting time.

Breaking things up is one of the first things you learn, and that *component architecture* allows you to break up into chunks that are semantically similar. This comes in handy so that the main element doesn't contain every bit of code but rather references to said code.

React is a great langauge that is well maintained and the market is saturated with React positions (although the downside is everyone will be lfor those positions, especially bootcamp grads).

Take the 5 minutes to download Node and npm and set up your editor if you haven't at the step where Bob points that out. It's nice to get used to the file architecture, the imports, and bascially the whole enviroment in Create React App. Also make sure you did the setup at 1:51:43 and that you have the right images files and stuff from the React site.

Next time I'll build the React Info App.

replies.text: You could try, but well, I'd say that JavaScript + ES6 syntax is highly recommended, and HTML is bare minimum, like you have to understand HTML. If you have such skills, I think you'll have it easy. If you want to also make your sites look nice, CSS is a must. But you can choose to pick it up at a later time, if you want to go with front-end ui kits/libraries (Example. Bootstrap, Material Design, Semantic UI, so on...). Hope this helped!

replies.text:
You will require knowledge of Let and const, arrow functions, Map method, ES6 classes and module system etc. There is an article about all prerequisites of React on Dev site by Nathan Sebhastian.

Though I will recommend that you must learn good amount of Javascript, OOP and web basics first before jumping to learn any library or framework.

book suggestion for Javascript 
: Eloquent Javascript by Marijn Haverbeke
